comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Excellent, rarely photographed tram line, think the Lawrences were one of the few to capture it.  Date 1890s?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Alexander Moon General Draper - better known as Moon's was still there up to 1995 when it was taken over by Brown Thomas (along with Switzer's, Todd's & Cash's) who now operate the business from the same location in Eglinton Buildings.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The Bank of Ireland building has been in continuous occupancy to the present day with very little change to the facade maps.google.ie/maps?q=williamsgate+street+galway&ll=5... The sign at the top is still there although a clock was added at some point since this photo was taken.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: D. Burke was Dominick Burke, a widower with six children (and two servants), postmaster and undertaker (1901 census www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Galway/Galway_N...) by 1911 there was no record of the family in the city.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: McCoy's hairdressers was a family business which opened in 1867 and was still there in 1911 www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Galway/Galway_N... Here's another photo of a group standing outside the hairdressers in the 1930's www.kennys.ie/booktalk/old-galway/changing-fashions-eyre-... The article tells us that the building next to it was the office of The Galway Pilot newspaper which you can just make out on the window signage here. Interestingly the same location is now the offices of The Galway Advertiser. Plus ca change...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/72163146@N08] so the earliest date for the photo is 1877 when the tramline was inaugurated Some more relevant articles from Kenny's here... www.kennys.ie/News/OldGalway/20052010_blacks_hotel/ www.kennys.ie/News/OldGalway/11092008-GalwaysFirstTaxiRank/ www.kennys.ie/News/OldGalway/31052007-EyreSquare/

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: And here's the House & Building return for 1901 which matches, as far as I can tell, the building uses in this photo www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai000808055/ (D.Burke's is listed on Rosemary Lane around the corner) It paints a picture of a vibrant hub of activity - but no closer to identifying the date except to say it's somewhere between 1877 and 1911 (D.Burke's had become James Ward's motor garage by 1911 www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai002380062/ )

comment.author: 29809546@N00
29809546@N00
comment._content:
Freeman's , Tuesday September 30th, 1879:
GALWAY AND SALTHILL TRAMWAY (SPECIAL TELEGRAM) Galway, Monday. The above work, which is completed, was inspected this afternoon by General Hutcheson, of the Board of Trade. The inspector walked over the line from the terminus, close to the railway station, to the terminus at Salthill, a distance of two miles and a quarter. General Hutcheson got into one of the tramcars at Salthill, accompanied by several gentlemen, besides eighteen outside. Mr Winby, the contractor, who has laid down the line, drove the tramcar himself with two splendid horses at a galloping pace into Galway, rounding all the curves on the line in a first-class style. General Hutcheson expressed himself highly satisfied, and pronounced it to be one of the best tramway lines yet laid down in these kingdoms.
So it must be (on or) after that date. 1877v 1879: In an account of a court case in 1885 (John Sands v Galway and Salthill Tramway Co) it says that "On 14th August 1877 the bill [under which the company was subsequently formed] received the Royal assent , but the line was not constructed till 1879, when it was taken over by Mr Winby, a contractor, who completed it."

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I passed this photo onto Felicity Hayes-McCoy whose grandfather ran McCoy's Haircutting Rooms and it led to this guest blog entry on Discover Ireland's website blog.discoverireland.com/2012/10/family-history-ireland/
